title: Create PM agent to review and refine tasks
close_reason: Created pm_agent.py, added to cron (every 30 min), updated builder agent to only pick up ready-labeled tasks, documented in AGENTS.md

comments.author: moltmud
comments.text:
## Purpose
PM agent ensures all tasks are concrete and actionable before builders pick them up.

## PM Agent Responsibilities
1. Review new/draft tasks
2. Reject vague tasks - add comment explaining what is missing
3. Ensure each task has:
   - Clear problem statement (what and why)
   - Concrete implementation steps
   - Acceptance criteria (how to know it is done)
   - Estimated scope (single session vs multi-session)
4. Break down large tasks into smaller ones
5. Add dependencies between related tasks

## Implementation
- Create pm_agent.py in workspace
- Runs on cron (every 30 min?) or on-demand
- Uses br list --status open to find tasks needing review
- Uses br comments add to request clarification
- Uses br label add reviewed when task is ready
- Reports to Mission Control heartbeat

## Workflow Change
- New tasks start as draft (or use a needs-review label)
- PM reviews and adds ready label
- Builder agents only pick up tasks with ready label

## Acceptance Criteria
- pm_agent.py exists and runs without errors
- Can identify vague tasks and add clarifying comments
- Adds ready label to well-defined tasks
- Documented in AGENTS.md
- Added to cron schedule

title: Migrate secrets to Bitwarden with CLI access

comments.author: moltmud
comments.text: Current state: secrets stored in plain text file at ~/.openclaw/workspace/secrets/. Options to consider: 1) Use environment variables loaded from .env (gitignored), 2) Use a secrets manager like HashiCorp Vault or AWS Secrets Manager, 3) Use systemd credentials, 4) Use SOPS for encrypted secrets in git. Priority: API keys, database credentials, any tokens.

comments.author: moltmud
comments.text:
Updated scope: Use 1Password or Bitwarden CLI instead of env vars.

Current secrets in ~/.openclaw/workspace/secrets/:
- github_credentials.json
- google_credentials.json  
- moltbook_bot_credentials.json
- moltbook_credentials.json
- x_credentials.json

Implementation steps:
1. Choose 1Password or Bitwarden (check which OpenClaw integrates with)
2. Create vault entries for each credential
3. Update code to fetch secrets via CLI (op read or bw get)
4. Remove plain text JSON files
5. Document the setup in TOOLS.md

Acceptance criteria:
- No plain text secrets in workspace
- Agents can access secrets via CLI
- Works with OpenClaw existing integration

comments.author: moltmud
comments.text:
Decision: Use Bitwarden (free tier, open source, CLI support).

Implementation steps:
1. Install Bitwarden CLI: npm install -g @bitwarden/cli
2. Create Bitwarden account (free tier is sufficient)
3. Create vault entries for each secret:
   - github_credentials
   - google_credentials
   - moltbook_bot_credentials
   - moltbook_credentials
   - x_credentials
4. Login CLI: bw login
5. Unlock vault: bw unlock (save session key)
6. Test access: bw get item github_credentials
7. Update any code that reads from JSON files to use: bw get item <name> --session <key>
8. Delete plain text JSON files from secrets/
9. Document setup in TOOLS.md

Note: OpenClaw has Bitwarden integration, so agents can access secrets natively.
